definitions: To lose blood from the body, typically as a result of injury or illness.
To draw blood from someone or something.
To extract fluid from a system, such as air from a brake line.
To allow or cause color to run or spread, especially in fabric.
To suffer a significant financial loss.
examples: The cut on his finger started to bleed.
The doctor had to bleed the patient to reduce swelling.
You need to bleed the brakes after replacing the fluid.
The red dye might bleed onto the white fabric.
The company continues to bleed money.
